columns.text: In this exercise, we'll see how many points we're ready to spend to lower the monthly payment APR from 4.3 percent to 4.05 percent on a $225,000 house loan mortgage over 30 years, assuming that a point is equal to 1% of the loan.

We will consider the following details when determining the number of points to spend:

| Particulars       |            |
|-------------------|------------|
| House loan amount | $225,000   |
| Original rate     | 4.30%      |
| Reduced rate     | 4.05%      |
| Period            | (30 years) |

Let's start by calculating the monthly payment using the 4.30% APR without the points.

To calculate the monthly payments, we'll use the PMT spreadsheet function. The PMT is a spreadsheet financial function that calculates periodic costs based on present value, rate, and period.

The spreadsheet function in the spreadsheet can be used using the following syntax:

$$\begin{aligned}
PMT&=(\text{rate},nper,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pv$, which represent the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year

We'll split the 4.3% rate by 12 because the APR is an annual rate, and we'll convert the period from 30 to 360  to represent the number of months in 30 years because we're computing a monthly payment.

Let's use the spreadsheet function PMT to determine the monthly payment. For the function to perform correctly, the present value must be negative.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/4bcf0222-b4f9-4fbd-a231-aaa239d2823b-1643550670762874.png)

As can be seen in our calculation, the monthly payment if the APR is 4.3% is $1,113.46.

Now, consider the alternative provided by the loan officer to reduce the APR from 4.30% to 4.05% if we pay a point onset of the loan. Let's calculate the total amount discounted from the initial offer if the APR is lowered to 4.05 by spending a particular number of points.

We will utilize the present value of an annuity computation to compute the amount discounted from the loan if the APR is dropped to 4.05% or otherwise the extra amount paid if the APR is 4.30%.

Although we already know the loan's present value is $225,000, in this calculation, we'll compute the loan's present value using the 4.05% APR assuming that we paid a particular number of points.

The following formula can be used to calculate the present value of an annuity:

$$ \begin{aligned}
PVA &=C\times\dfrac{1-\dfrac{1}{\left(1+r\right)^t}}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PVA$, which means the present value of an annuity\
$C$, which represent the periodic amount\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

The following details will be taken into account in this calculation:

| Particulars       |            |
|-------------------|------------|
| Monthly payment | $1,113.46   |
| Reduced rate     | 4.05%      |
| Period            | (30 years) |

Similarly to the first computation, for the reason that we are calculating a monthly payment, we will split the 4.05% rate by 12 because the APR is an annual rate, and we'll convert the period from yearly base to monthly base; hence, the period is 360.

Let's now calculate the amount discounted from the loan if we pay a particular point.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Amount Discounted} &= \$231,824.96-\$225,000
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\$6,824.96}
\end{aligned}$$

As a result, as shown above, the total savings from the alternative is $6,824.96.
Finally, let's consider the total amount discounted from the alternative to determine the number of points we should spend to lower the loan's APR rate from 4.30% to 4.05%

We will divide the amount discounted over the loan amount and multiply the result by 100. Hence we will use the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Maximum Point to Spend} &= \dfrac{\text{Amount Discounted}}{\text{Loan amount}}\times100
\end{aligned}$$

Let's now calculate the maximum percentage of points we can spend.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Maximum Point to Spend} &= \dfrac{\$6,824.96}{\$225,000}\times100
\\[10pt]
&= \boxed{{\text{\bf3.033 Points}}}
\end{aligned}$$

**Therefore, as seen in our calculation, the maximum point we can spend to lower the APR is 3.033 points.**

To deduce, the maximum point we can pay for the APR of the loan to lower is 3.033. We determined the number of points by calculating the amount of discount we can get from the alternative offer and dividing it over the present value of the loan multiplied by a hundred.
